Applications of tripple and higher integrals

The integral \(\displaystyle\int \displaystyle\int \displaystyle\int f(x,y,z) \;\mathrm{d}z \,\mathrm{d}y\,\mathrm{d}x\) (or \(\displaystyle\int_V f(x,y,z) \;\mathrm{d}V)\) may represent many physical quantities depending on the function \(f(x,y,z)\) and the limits used.

Volume

The integral \(\displaystyle\int_V 1 \;\mathrm{d}V\) (i.e. the integral of the function \(f(x,y,z)=1\)) with appropriate limits gives the volume of the solid described by \(V\). This is sometimes more convenient than finding the volume by means of a double integral.

Mass

The integral \(\displaystyle\int \displaystyle\int \displaystyle\int \rho(x,y,z) \;\mathrm{d}z\,\mathrm{d}y\,\mathrm{d}x\) (or \(\displaystyle\int_V \rho(x,y,z) \;\mathrm{d}V\)), with appropriate limits, gives the mass of the solid bounded by \(V\).
